div.head: AN ACCOUNT OF THE CEREMONY OF INVESTING His ELECTORAL HIGHNESS OF BRANDENBÆ²RGH; WITH THE Order of the Garter. PERFORM'D At Berlin on the 6th of June, 1690.

By James JohnÅ¿ton EÅ¿q His MajeÅ¿ties Envoy extraordinary to His Electoral HighneÅ¿s, and Principal CommiÅ¿Å¿ioner. And Gregory King EÅ¿q the other CommiÅ¿Å¿ioner for this InveÅ¿titure. div.p:
WE arrived here on TueÅ¿day the 27th of May, Old Å¿tile, with Mr. JohnÅ¿ton, His MajeÅ¿ties Envoy extraordinary; and Mr. King, CommiÅ¿Å¿ioner for the InveÅ¿titure. The The Elector came hither PoÅ¿t on the Saturday thereafter, from Coningsberg. On Monday following, being the Å¿econd of June, the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners had a privat Audience; at which they delivered the Credential Letters and Book of Statutes; after which they put on the Elector the Ribbon-Garter and George. âThey had likewiÅ¿e a privat Audience
of Her Electoral HighneÅ¿s, of the PrinceÅ¿s ElectreÅ¿s, and of the Margraff, and two other Princes, the Elector's Brothers. This they did for the diÅ¿patch, and that they might have the freedom of going to Court, and Å¿eing the adjuÅ¿ting of the States, and the putting of all other things in Order, againÅ¿t the time of the Solemn InveÅ¿titure. But they could not have a publick Audience, nor could the Ceremony of InveÅ¿titure be performed, till the Elector's Court, and his Coaches and HorÅ¿es Å¿hould arrive; which hapned on ThurÅ¿day night. In the mean time all other things were made ready, and the next day, being Friday the 6th of June, was appointed both for the publick Audience, and the Ceremony of InveÅ¿titure. The CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners were willing that theÅ¿e two Å¿hould be joined together, that no time might be loÅ¿t, nor the Elector's Journey to the Rhine Å¿topt Å¿o much as one moment, upon the account of the Solemnity.

On Friday morning the Baron of Shiarm, the eldeÅ¿t Privy CounÅ¿ellor, or MiniÅ¿ter of State (as they Å¿peak here) came from Court, accompanied with a great many other Gentlemen, and particularly with MonÅ¿ieur BeÅ¿cat, (whoÅ¿e Office it was to regulat the Ceremony) all in Rich Cloaths, with Å¿ix of the Elector's Coaches, and Å¿ix HorÅ¿es in each of them, and carried the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners and their Retinue to Court; twenty four Trabants, or HorÅ¿e-Guards, walking along all the way on both Å¿ides of the Coaches: Not to mention a great many of the Elector's Servants that did alÅ¿o attend them. At Court they were received with Double Guards, and Colours DiÅ¿played, Twenty four Trumpets, and two pair of Kettle-Drums Å¿ounding all the while. The CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners Coach paÅ¿Å¿ed through the Inner-Court of the CaÅ¿tle; at the foot of the Stairs the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners were received by the Grand MarÅ¿hal, with his Silver Staff of Office: At the head of the Stairs they were met by the Elector's Great Chamberlain, the Count of Denherff, and Å¿o were conducted to the Elector's Chamber; all the Rooms, as they paÅ¿s along, being full of the Nobility and Gentry of the Court, and the Trebants making the Guard up the Stairs, and along the two firÅ¿t Rooms.

From the Elector's Apartment, they went to an Audience of the Electrice, where were all the Princes and PrinceÅ¿Å¿es of the Family, and the Ladies of the Court, richly dreÅ¿Å¿ed: Then they were conducted to the Rooms where the Robes of Order were before placed, where all
things being in readineÅ¿s, they went to another Room near adjoining, in which his Electoral HighneÅ¿s was, and thence began the ProceÅ¿Å¿ion to the Great Hall, which is one of the nobleÅ¿t Rooms that is to be Å¿een any where, being above 100 foot long, and above 50 foot broad, adorn'd all about with the Marble Statues of the Electors of the Family, and the Roof richly painted. They went in this Order: FirÅ¿t, The Nobility and Officers of the Court in great number; The Grand MarÅ¿hal and MarÅ¿hal with their Silver Staves of Office, being the laÅ¿t of them. Next came two belonging to the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, one of them carrying the King's CommiÅ¿Å¿ion, and the other the Cap and Feather; then followed Mr. Gregory King in the Mantle of the Kings at Arms, bearing the Habit and EnÅ¿igns of the Order on a Velvet CuÅ¿hion. Next came Mr. JohnÅ¿ton alone; and in the laÅ¿t place his Electoral HighneÅ¿s, attended by the Prince of Anhalt, and the Grand Chamberlain.

Thus they went through a long Gallery (having the Trabants on each Å¿ide) into the Hall, and Å¿o into the Rails which divided the upper end of the Hall, that was raiÅ¿ed four Steps, making the due Reverences to the Soveraign's State; the Electrice, with the PrinceÅ¿Å¿es and Princes Ladies, and publick MiniÅ¿ters, having before taken their places within the Rails.

The Elector being placed under his State, and the Robes being laid on a Table near his HighneÅ¿s, the two CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners Å¿eated themÅ¿elves in two armed Chairs, and the Trumpets and MuÅ¿ick ceaÅ¿ing, Mr. JohnÅ¿ton made a DiÅ¿courÅ¿e in EngliÅ¿h. But not to oblige the Elector to Å¿tand, becauÅ¿e of an hurt in his Leg, the Expedient fallen upon was this; That in Å¿tead of four DiÅ¿courÅ¿es (as the CuÅ¿tom is) two by one of the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, and two by one belonging to the Elector; that one only Å¿hould be made by Mr. JohnÅ¿ton in the beginning, and another at the end of the Ceremony by MonÅ¿ieur Fulks, one of the Elector's MiniÅ¿ters of State. And therefore Mr. JohnÅ¿ton having put his two DiÅ¿courÅ¿es into one, and having only told the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of them in EngliÅ¿h, he preÅ¿ented a TranÅ¿lation in High Dutch to the Elector, which he ordered his Chief Secretary to read; the Elector and the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners having Å¿tood during the pronouncing of the EngliÅ¿h, but Å¿itting when the Dutch Copy was read. Then they preÅ¿ented the King's CommiÅ¿Å¿ion to the Elector, which he gave to a MiniÅ¿ter of Å¿tate, who ãâã it to the Secretary to be read, the Elector and all others Å¿tanding
up; which being again delivered to the Elector, his HighneÅ¿s gave it to Mr. King; After which, the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners having taken off his HighneÅ¿s'âª Coat, Sword, Belt, Ribbon George and Garter, Mr. Johnston inveÅ¿ted the Elector with the Diamond Garter, the Surcoat, the Sword and Belt, the great Mantle, the Hood, and at laÅ¿t the great Collar and George, in the order as they were delivered to him by Mr. King; who pronounced in Latin the uÅ¿ual Forms of Admonitions upon Mr. Johnston's putting on the Elector each EnÅ¿ign. Then they preÅ¿ented to his Electoral HighneÅ¿s the Book of Statutes under the great Seal of the Order, and he delivered them Letters certifying his reception of the Order, and containing an Engagement to obÅ¿erve the Statutes with the uÅ¿ual Exceptions. TheÅ¿e Letters had already his Sign, and Seal at them, yet his Electoral HighneÅ¿s had a Pen given him, and he made a Å¿hew of writing his Name.
Next they preÅ¿ented him with the Cap and Feather, which his Electoral HighneÅ¿s had enriched with Diamonds to the value of above 50000 l. one of the Å¿tones coÅ¿t above 10000 l.
Then Mr. King did congratulate his Electoral HighneÅ¿s, and proclaimed the Soveraigns and New-Knights Titles, upon which the Trumpets Å¿ounded, and the Drums beat, and MuÅ¿ick play'd.

This being over, Mr. JohnÅ¿ton did alÅ¿o congratulate his HighneÅ¿s in in a Å¿hort Complement, and then MonÅ¿ieur Fulks made an handÅ¿ome Speech to the praiÅ¿e of the Soveraign and the Order. This Speech was in High-Dutch, that it might be underÅ¿tood by the whole AÅ¿Å¿embly; and a Copy of it being given to Mr. Stepney, Mr. Johnston's Secretary, he read it publickly, the Elector and CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners Å¿itting all the while that MonÅ¿ieur Fulks Å¿poke, and that the Copy was read. Then they preÅ¿ented the Stars or Glories, and the Riboon of the Order; and returning to their Chairs, the Drums beat, the Trumpets Å¿ounded, and the Cannon round the Town was thrice diÅ¿charged. Then the Elector and CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners returned in proceÅ¿Å¿ion as they came, and Mr. Norton, Collonel Norton's GrandÅ¿on, he had the honour to carry the Elector's Train.

A little after this, they came back to the Hall again to Dinner, where his Electoral HighneÅ¿s and the two CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners only did Å¿it at the Table, his HighneÅ¿s being in the Robes, and the Court attending: The Elector began firÅ¿t the King's Health; 2dly, the Queen's; 3dly ãâã
Knights of the Order; 4thly, ProÅ¿perity to the EngliÅ¿h Nation; 5thly, SucceÅ¿s to the Campaign. Mr. Johnston began firÅ¿t the Elector's Health; 2dly, the Electorices; 3dly, the Electoral Families; the Elector and CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners Å¿tood up, and the Guns were diÅ¿charged at every GlaÅ¿s. After Dinner the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners were carried home in the Å¿ame manner as they were brought in the morning; at night they returned to Court in two Coaches with Å¿ix HorÅ¿es, and Å¿upp'd with the Elector, the Electrice, and the PrinceÅ¿s, where many of the Å¿ame Healths were drunk again with the Å¿ame Ceremony of firing, and Å¿tanding up.

After supper the Fire-works began, and were much admired by every one, conÅ¿idering they had only three days to prepare them: There were many Rockets of all Å¿orts, and four great Fire-works of 40 or 50 foot high, the chief burnt blew, and was compoÅ¿ed of the repreÅ¿entation of a Garter, having within it theÅ¿e four Letters, V. W. M. R. Å¿ignifying Vivant Willielmus Maria Reges; and without the Garter were the Å¿upporting Crown and CreÅ¿t of England. The other three were Pyramids burning in bright white fire, with Crowns on the tops of them; the middlemoÅ¿t having the Letter B. and the other two, F. and H. Å¿ignifying Britannia, Francia, Hibernia. The Elector hath ordered the Garter to be put on the Plate. Ever Å¿ince the publick Audience, we have been entertained at our Lodgings at the Elector's charge, and attended by his Officers. Both the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners have received Rich PreÅ¿ents, the principal CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners being double the value of what was given to the other. The Servants of the firÅ¿t, to the number of 16, and thoÅ¿e of the other CommiÅ¿Å¿ioner, 3, had all conÅ¿iderable PreÅ¿ents according to their Å¿everal Offices. In a word, every thing was done for the honour of the Soveraign of it, and of the new Knight; and in a manner more noble than it could have been expected the Å¿hortneÅ¿s of time would have allow'd.

div.p: NOthing excites in men the deÅ¿ire of Glory Å¿o much as Å¿ignal and laÅ¿ting marks of Honour. For to Noble and Generous Minds, Honour is certainly the greateÅ¿t Reward, and Å¿uch marks are the moÅ¿t acceptable ãâã of it to wit, a publick acknowledgment that men ãâã .

Of theÅ¿e marks, the moÅ¿t eminent have been appropriated to Chevalry. Religion hath its TreaÅ¿ury above. JuÅ¿tice, and the other peaceable Virtues without Arms, would be of little or no uÅ¿e. Therefore Military Glory, as moÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿ary, hath been preferr'd to all others; beÅ¿ides, it is acquired with greater danger, and is founded on nobler PaÅ¿Å¿ions.
AmongÅ¿t all incitements to it, nothing hath proved Å¿o effectual as the InÅ¿titution of the Orders of Knights, Companions and Brethren.

Such Orders do engage Princes by the Å¿tricteÅ¿t Ties of Honour, to give in their own PerÅ¿ons an example of Military Virtue, as alÅ¿o the higheÅ¿t Incouragement imaginable to follow it: For by theÅ¿e Fraternities they deÅ¿cend from their GreatneÅ¿s, and conÅ¿ent, that brave and gallant Men Å¿hould be brought into a Å¿ort of Equality with themÅ¿elves.

AmongÅ¿t Military Orders, there are none that can diÅ¿pute either Antiquity or Dignity with that of the Garter; which may indeed be called the Mother Order, For the other great Orders have Å¿prung out of this Root, being formed upon the Model of it.

Such InÅ¿titutions, like other things of the Å¿ame nature, in their firÅ¿t conceptions uÅ¿e to be imperfect, and calculated for receiving the Reformations that time only brings: But the Rules of this Order were from the beginning Å¿o well digeÅ¿ted, that they have admitted of few or no material Changes.

To the Antiquity and WiÅ¿dom of the InÅ¿titution, I may add the ChaÅ¿tity of the Order: The Knights have at no time exceeded the firÅ¿t foundation of Twenty Å¿ix, contrary to the fate of other Orders, of which none have Å¿upported their Dignity as this hath done, conÅ¿idering jointly the Å¿mal number, and Å¿ingular eminency of thoÅ¿e that have been of it, viz. Four hundred ninty Å¿even only. And yet amongÅ¿t theÅ¿e, there have been eight Emperors (of whom two, SigiÅ¿mond, and Charles the Vth went to England and received it there, Å¿o much did they value the Honour of being of it;) Forty five Kings, including thoÅ¿e of England; and above Å¿ixty Princes, for the moÅ¿t part Soveraigns; Not to mention that the others generally deÅ¿erving to be Princes, were therefore by the Order in a manner made Å¿uch.

The Qualities of Edward III. who founded this Order, gave a peculiar LuÅ¿tre to it; He was the GreateÅ¿t and BraveÅ¿t Prince of his Time, in the opinion of all others, as well as of the Germans, who firÅ¿t made Him Vicar-General of the Empire, and afterwards offered ãâ¦ã perial Diadem.

He claimed the Crown of France as his JuÅ¿t and Lawful Inheritance, and Å¿tudied by the InÅ¿titution of this Order, to engage the moÅ¿t martial Spirits of the Age, in his Quarrel. It was with his Garter that he gave the Signal at the Battel of CreÅ¿Å¿ey; remembering, it Å¿eems, that which was reported of one of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors, Richard the 1Å¿t, That he had upon a like occaÅ¿ion, with great SucceÅ¿s, made uÅ¿e of a Garter. In this Battel the whole Power of France fell before Him; upon which Augury he made the Garter the chief Sign of the Order. Richard the 1st, is alÅ¿o Å¿aid upon Å¿uch an account to have had the Å¿ame deÅ¿ign. BeÅ¿ides, a Garter is the Symbol and Badg of Unity, and therefore moÅ¿t proper to Å¿ignifie theÅ¿e Bonds of Amity and Affection, into which all the Companions were to reckon themÅ¿elves knit.

He delighted much in Devices, and choÅ¿e for the Device of the Order, theÅ¿e words, Honi Å¿oit qui mal y PenÅ¿e; in EngliÅ¿h, May he be aÅ¿hamed that thinks ill (or does not approve) of it. That is, either of the Order it Å¿elf, or of his Title to the Crown of France, which gave occaÅ¿ion to the InÅ¿titution.

He made Blew the chief Colour, that being the Colour of the Field of the Arms of France, which, with the Title he had about that time aÅ¿Å¿umed to himÅ¿elf, his SucceÅ¿Å¿ors have ever Å¿ince uÅ¿ed: BeÅ¿ides, Blew denotes the Sublime and CeleÅ¿tial Temper of thoÅ¿e who were to be of the Order. The Pilgrims that returned from the Holy Land, brought over Å¿uch an account of St. George (then the ChriÅ¿tian Mars) particularly of his Tutelary care of the EngliÅ¿h in that War, that according to the PerÅ¿uaÅ¿ions of thoÅ¿e Times, he made him the Patron of the Order, as well as of the Nation.

He wiÅ¿ely conÅ¿idered that other Sovereign Princes might think it a leÅ¿Å¿ening of them, to come into an Order Å¿ubject to the Laws and Government of England; therefore he intirely Å¿eparated its Concerns, and made it a diÅ¿tinct Body with Seals and Officers, and Statutes peculiar to it; over which the Seals and Laws of England have no Å¿ort of Authority.

This is the Order, Sir, Å¿o deÅ¿ervedly famous over all ChriÅ¿tendom, theÅ¿e Three hundred and forty Years, of which we have now the Honor, in the Name of the King our MaÅ¿ter, to PreÅ¿ent Your Electoral HighneÅ¿s the EnÅ¿igns. The Å¿ame Order which His HighneÅ¿s, Your IlluÅ¿trious Father, deÅ¿ired Å¿o much, and received as a great Honour done
him, and to which he did great Honour: He wore it in a time of Action, when the Fate not only of the North, but of the whole Empire; nay, I may add, of all Europe, turned according to the MeaÅ¿ures that he took, and which is more, turned often with the approbation of all good men. It was thus that he run his Career, which he finiÅ¿hed with an happineÅ¿s that might be called the obtaining of the Prize, if that were to be done here; For he being full of Honour and Years, in Peace and Quiet, Belov'd and EÅ¿teem'd by the better part of Mankind, died; leaving behind him the only Two things to be left, a Great and Good Name, and a Glorious SucceÅ¿Å¿or.

It is alÅ¿o the Å¿ame Garter, as well as the Å¿ame Order, with which we are to inveÅ¿t your HighneÅ¿s. This I Å¿hould call a happy Omen, that the Order is Å¿till to receive the Å¿ame Honour: But your HighneÅ¿s hath not left the World to Divination and Conjecture; you have begun your Regence in a way worthy of the Son of Å¿uch a Father, and already given Mankind real inÅ¿tances of that which they may expect: And now this day you are to put the Order in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Honour which you have, as it were, advanced to it, and to which the Order hath a Natural Claim, your HighneÅ¿s having acquired the Å¿ame, as the Founder did his, by defeating the acient Enemies of both Nations. For this ReaÅ¿on, I Å¿uppoÅ¿e, the King, my MaÅ¿ter, as well as for doing your HighneÅ¿s greater Honour, hath Å¿ent you a Sword, amongÅ¿t the EnÅ¿igns of the Order, which hitherto was never done to any other.

Sir, Nothing is more evident than that this Society was inÅ¿tituted for carrying on a War with France, in which War, the Emperor, the Princes of Brandenburg, Bavaria, Lorrain, and many others, were engaged by a Confederacy with the Founder of this Order, as your HighneÅ¿s, and others, their SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, are now with the preÅ¿ent Soveraign of it. It Å¿eems in all Ages it hath been the WiÅ¿dom of Great Princes to have no other thing to do with that Crown. Sure that which hath hapned in this Age, doth not alter the CaÅ¿e; nay, the preÅ¿ent Confederacy is a DemonÅ¿tration, that it is the SenÅ¿e of Mankind, that the Publick quiet can be no longer Å¿ecured by the Faith of Treaties; and therefore, that a firm Peace is only to be obtained by a thorough War: For Men that having enriched themÅ¿elves by Violence, are fallen in love with it, will love on till they loÅ¿e by it, then it will be Å¿eaÅ¿onable. To truÅ¿t to Treaties, the incapacity Å¿uch Men Å¿hall be in to break them, ãâ¦ã .

Edward the 3d deÅ¿igned a ConqueÅ¿t, and Å¿ucceeded in it: But there is here place for yet a more Noble DeÅ¿ign, that of a Redemption. The Work of an Hero is not to mind his own BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s only, much leÅ¿s to do hurt, to plunder the World with Alexander, or ruine his own Countrey with CaeÅ¿ar; but to do good chiefly to others; to chain up the DiÅ¿turbers of the Publick Peace, to Å¿et Bounds to Exorbitant Power, and the Will of Man; and Å¿o to deÅ¿erve the BleÅ¿Å¿ings of thoÅ¿e that were ready to periÅ¿h. All this the King, my MaÅ¿ter, hath done, by redeeming his own Countrey from Ruine, and other Countreys from the danger of it, in Å¿uffering them to become his own: Thus endeavouring every where to Å¿tem the Inundations of the preÅ¿ent Times, as his Ancestors did thoÅ¿e of theirs.

But to this, not only the Example of the Soveraign invites thoÅ¿e of the Order, but the Order it Å¿elf, in a particular manner, engages them, Pugnare pro jure & tuitione oppreÅ¿Å¿orum & indigentium, To fight for the relief of the poor and the oppreÅ¿Å¿ed.

This, ReaÅ¿on, Humanity, common ChriÅ¿tianity, and IntereÅ¿t too, requires of all Men, much more of Princes, that are to act as Gods Vicegerents, who Glories in nothing oftner than in his firm purpoÅ¿es to avenge and Protect Widows and Orphans, and Å¿uch others, the Innocent, though Unfortunate part of Mankind, to wit, by commanding all thoÅ¿e that have power to do it, to puniÅ¿h their OppreÅ¿Å¿ors.

Thus it is here, That a Capacity to do good, not only gives a Title to it, but makes the doing of it a Duty. It is Å¿trange, That among ChriÅ¿tians in all Times there Å¿hould have been Å¿ome who doubted of this, and have had narrower Thoughts of Heroical Enterprizes than either the Jews or Heathens had; nay, of whom Å¿ome have believ'd all War to be unlawful, Å¿ince the DeÅ¿ign of ChriÅ¿tianity was to exalt our Natures to a higher and Å¿ublimer pitch of Perfection, and not to Å¿tifle and undo, with Å¿pecious pretences, that which is moÅ¿t Commendable in them, the Inclinations and Ties we may have to do one another good.

The Jews of old had Å¿o Noble an Opinion of Å¿uch Performances, that they imputed them to InÅ¿piration; they thought, that without extraordinary AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tances, Men had neither GoodneÅ¿s nor LargeneÅ¿s of Soul Å¿ufficient for them.

It is true, Å¿everal among them endeavoured thus to defend the Irregularities that Å¿ometimes did accompany Å¿uch Actions, and Å¿uppoÅ¿ed an expreÅ¿s Order from Godâª as neceÅ¿Å¿ary to juÅ¿tifie them. Yet Rules and
Laws are means for obtaining the ends which they relate to, and in that relation cannot be too well obÅ¿erved; but they are not the ends themÅ¿elves which muÅ¿t Å¿till be purÅ¿ued, tho in another way, if the ordinary way fails. No doubt the Letter of the Law, that upon great occaÅ¿ions oppoÅ¿es it Å¿elf to the publick Safety, which is intended by all Laws, muÅ¿t needs be the Letter that kills.
